arguments.info: A list of tag IDs to apply to this object.

attributes.info: A list of tag IDs to apply to this object.

arguments.info: The ID of the datacenter. Can be ignored if creating a datacenter folder, otherwise required.
The path of the folder and any parents, relative to the datacenter and folder type being defined.
A list of tag IDs to apply to this object.
The type of the folder.

attributes.info: The ID of the datacenter. Can be ignored if creating a datacenter folder, otherwise required.
The path of the folder and any parents, relative to the datacenter and folder type being defined.
A list of tag IDs to apply to this object.
The type of the folder.

arguments.info: List of active network adapters used for load balancing.
Controls whether or not the virtual network adapter is allowed to send network traffic with a different MAC address than that of its own.
Controls whether or not the Media Access Control (MAC) address can be changed.
Enable promiscuous mode on the network. This flag indicates whether or not all traffic is seen on a given port.
Enable beacon probing. Requires that the vSwitch has been configured to use a beacon. If disabled, link status is used only.
If true, the teaming policy will re-activate failed interfaces higher in precedence when they come back up.
The managed object ID of the host to set the virtual switch up on.
The name of the port group.
If true, the teaming policy will notify the broadcast network of a NIC failover, triggering cache updates.
The average bandwidth in bits per second if shaping is enabled on the port.
The maximum burst size allowed in bytes if shaping is enabled on the port.
True if the traffic shaper is enabled on the port.
The peak bandwidth during bursts in bits per second if traffic shaping is enabled on the port.
List of standby network adapters used for failover.
The network adapter teaming policy. Can be one of loadbalance_ip, loadbalance_srcmac, loadbalance_srcid, or failover_explicit.
The name of the virtual switch to bind this port group to.

The VLAN ID/trunk mode for this port group. An ID of 0 denotes no tagging, an ID of 1-4094 tags with the specific ID, and an ID of 4095 enables trunk mode, allowing the guest to manage its own tagging.

attributes.info: List of active network adapters used for load balancing.
Controls whether or not the virtual network adapter is allowed to send network traffic with a different MAC address than that of its own.
Controls whether or not the Media Access Control (MAC) address can be changed.
Enable promiscuous mode on the network. This flag indicates whether or not all traffic is seen on a given port.
Enable beacon probing. Requires that the vSwitch has been configured to use a beacon. If disabled, link status is used only.
The effective network policy after inheritance. Note that this will look similar to, but is not the same, as the policy attributes defined in this resource.
If true, the teaming policy will re-activate failed interfaces higher in precedence when they come back up.
The managed object ID of the host to set the virtual switch up on.
The linkable identifier for this port group.
The name of the port group.
If true, the teaming policy will notify the broadcast network of a NIC failover, triggering cache updates.
The ports that currently exist and are used on this port group.

subblock.info: The linkable identifier for this port entry.
The MAC addresses of the network service of the virtual machine connected on this port.
Type type of the entity connected on this port. Possible values are host (VMKkernel), systemManagement (service console), virtualMachine, or unknown.

attributes.info: The average bandwidth in bits per second if shaping is enabled on the port.
The maximum burst size allowed in bytes if shaping is enabled on the port.
True if the traffic shaper is enabled on the port.
The peak bandwidth during bursts in bits per second if traffic shaping is enabled on the port.
List of standby network adapters used for failover.
The network adapter teaming policy. Can be one of loadbalance_ip, loadbalance_srcmac, loadbalance_srcid, or failover_explicit.
The name of the virtual switch to bind this port group to.

The VLAN ID/trunk mode for this port group. An ID of 0 denotes no tagging, an ID of 1-4094 tags with the specific ID, and an ID of 4095 enables trunk mode, allowing the guest to manage its own tagging.

arguments.info: List of active network adapters used for load balancing.
Controls whether or not the virtual network adapter is allowed to send network traffic with a different MAC address than that of its own.
Controls whether or not the Media Access Control (MAC) address can be changed.
Enable promiscuous mode on the network. This flag indicates whether or not all traffic is seen on a given port.
Determines how often, in seconds, a beacon should be sent to probe for the validity of a link.
Enable beacon probing. Requires that the vSwitch has been configured to use a beacon. If disabled, link status is used only.
If true, the teaming policy will re-activate failed interfaces higher in precedence when they come back up.
The managed object ID of the host to set the virtual switch up on.
Whether to advertise or listen for link discovery. Valid values are advertise, both, listen, and none.
The discovery protocol type. Valid values are cdp and lldp.
The maximum transmission unit (MTU) of the virtual switch in bytes.
The name of the virtual switch.
The list of network adapters to bind to this virtual switch.
If true, the teaming policy will notify the broadcast network of a NIC failover, triggering cache updates.
The number of ports that this virtual switch is configured to use.
The average bandwidth in bits per second if shaping is enabled on the port.
The maximum burst size allowed in bytes if shaping is enabled on the port.
True if the traffic shaper is enabled on the port.
The peak bandwidth during bursts in bits per second if traffic shaping is enabled on the port.
List of standby network adapters used for failover.
The network adapter teaming policy. Can be one of loadbalance_ip, loadbalance_srcmac, loadbalance_srcid, or failover_explicit.

Determines how often, in seconds, a beacon should be sent to probe for the validity of a link.
Enable beacon probing. Requires that the vSwitch has been configured to use a beacon. If disabled, link status is used only.
If true, the teaming policy will re-activate failed interfaces higher in precedence when they come back up.
The managed object ID of the host to set the virtual switch up on.
Whether to advertise or listen for link discovery. Valid values are advertise, both, listen, and none.
The discovery protocol type. Valid values are cdp and lldp.
The maximum transmission unit (MTU) of the virtual switch in bytes.
The name of the virtual switch.
The list of network adapters to bind to this virtual switch.
If true, the teaming policy will notify the broadcast network of a NIC failover, triggering cache updates.
The number of ports that this virtual switch is configured to use.
The average bandwidth in bits per second if shaping is enabled on the port.
The maximum burst size allowed in bytes if shaping is enabled on the port.
True if the traffic shaper is enabled on the port.
The peak bandwidth during bursts in bits per second if traffic shaping is enabled on the port.
List of standby network adapters used for failover.
The network adapter teaming policy. Can be one of loadbalance_ip, loadbalance_srcmac, loadbalance_srcid, or failover_explicit.

arguments.info: Access mode for the mount point. Can be one of readOnly or readWrite.
The path to the datastore folder to put the datastore in.
The managed object IDs of the hosts to mount the datastore on.
The name of the datastore.
The hostnames or IP addresses of the remote server or servers. Only one element should be present for NFS v3 but multiple can be present for NFS v4.1.
The remote path of the mount point.
The security type to use.
A list of tag IDs to apply to this object.
The type of NAS volume. Can be one of NFS (to denote v3) or NFS41 (to denote NFS v4.1).

attributes.info: Access mode for the mount point. Can be one of readOnly or readWrite.
The connectivity status of the datastore. If this is false, some other computed attributes may be out of date.
Maximum capacity of the datastore, in MB.
The path to the datastore folder to put the datastore in.
Available space of this datastore, in MB.
The managed object IDs of the hosts to mount the datastore on.
The current maintenance mode state of the datastore.
If true, more than one host in the datacenter has been configured with access to the datastore.
The name of the datastore.
Indicates that this NAS volume is a protocol endpoint. This field is only populated if the host supports virtual datastores.
The hostnames or IP addresses of the remote server or servers. Only one element should be present for NFS v3 but multiple can be present for NFS v4.1.
The remote path of the mount point.
The security type to use.
A list of tag IDs to apply to this object.
The type of NAS volume. Can be one of NFS (to denote v3) or NFS41 (to denote NFS v4.1).
Total additional storage space, in MB, potentially used by all virtual machines on this datastore.
The unique locator for the datastore.

arguments.info: The unique identifier of the parent category in which this tag will be created.
The description of the tag.
The display name of the tag. The name must be unique within its category.

attributes.info: The unique identifier of the parent category in which this tag will be created.
The description of the tag.
The display name of the tag. The name must be unique within its category.

arguments.info: Object types to which this category's tags can be attached.
The associated cardinality of the category. Can be one of SINGLE (object can only be assigned one tag in this category) or MULTIPLE (object can be assigned multiple tags in this category).
The description of the category.
The display name of the category.

attributes.info: Object types to which this category's tags can be attached.
The associated cardinality of the category. Can be one of SINGLE (object can only be assigned one tag in this category) or MULTIPLE (object can be assigned multiple tags in this category).
The description of the category.
The display name of the category.

arguments.info: The name of the datacenter. This can be a name or path.	Can be omitted if there is only one datacenter in your inventory.

attributes.info: The name of the datacenter. This can be a name or path.	Can be omitted if there is only one datacenter in your inventory.

arguments.info: The managed object ID of the datacenter to look for the host in.
The name of the host. This can be a name or path.	If not provided, the default host is used.

attributes.info: The managed object ID of the datacenter to look for the host in.
The name of the host. This can be a name or path.	If not provided, the default host is used.

The description of the category.
The display name of the category.

arguments.info: A regular expression to filter the disks against. Only disks with canonical names that match will be included.
The managed object ID of the host to search for disks on.
Rescan the system for disks before querying. This may lengthen the time it takes to gather information.

attributes.info: The names of the disks discovered by the search.
A regular expression to filter the disks against. Only disks with canonical names that match will be included.
The managed object ID of the host to search for disks on.
Rescan the system for disks before querying. This may lengthen the time it takes to gather information.
